enhanced_description: Green Curry (Gaeng Keow Wan) is Thai cuisine's emerald jewel - a coconut curry that perfectly balances creamy richness with herbaceous heat. Unlike its red and yellow cousins, green curry gets its color and flavor from fresh green chilies and herbs, making it bright, aromatic, and surprisingly complex. The name literally means 'sweet green curry' but don't be fooled - it packs serious heat.

detailed_ingredients.name: Green Curry Paste
detailed_ingredients.purpose: The soul of the dish - fresh herbs and chilies ground together

detailed_ingredients.name: Thai Eggplant
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Adds texture and absorbs the curry flavors

detailed_ingredients.name: Thai Basil
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Fresh aromatic finish that brightens the rich curry

detailed_ingredients.name: Coconut Cream
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Creates the rich base and tempers the heat

cooking_method.steps_overview: The secret is 'cracking' the coconut cream - heating it until the oil separates, then frying the curry paste in this oil. This blooming process is crucial for developing deep flavors before adding liquids.
cooking_tips: Fry curry paste until incredibly fragrant - this is key
Use the thick part of coconut milk first
Don't boil vigorously - gentle simmer preserves color
Add vegetables by cooking time - hardest first
Finish with basil off the heat

cultural_significance.origin_story: Developed in Central Thailand's royal kitchens, green curry represents the sophistication of palace cuisine. The use of fresh herbs instead of dried spices shows the abundance of Thailand's herbs.
cultural_significance.cultural_importance: Green curry is a test of a cook's skill - balancing heat, sweetness, and salt while maintaining the bright green color. It's considered more refined than red curry and is often served at important dinners.
